thread.title: Columbia gets key football win over La Salle
thread.title_full: Columbia gets key football win over La Salle - Times Union

author: Eric Houghtaling
title: Columbia gets key football win over La Salle
text:
East Greenbush
Bruising back Dylan Dubuque rushed for more than 250 yards and Columbia High won a key Class AA Liberty Division seeding game 28-7 over La Salle on Friday.
Dubuque ran for three touchdowns for the Blue Devils, benefiting from stellar blocking from the offensive line in the win.
Columbia's defense, meanwhile, also controlled the line of scrimmage in limiting the Cadets to just one touchdown.
"We struggled a bit last week up front, so we got after guys in practice this week and really tried to encourage them," coach Craig Cavotta said. "We stressed that most games are won in the trenches and they showed up tonight. I thought the lines on both sides of the ball played great."
Dubuque broke tackles, eluded defenders and at times, carried three or four would-be tacklers on his way to 257 yards on 35 carries.
His 14-yard TD run with 3:29 left in the second quarter broke a scoreless tie.
"We had some trouble those first two drives, but we stepped up and just grounded out the first downs," Dubuque said. "This was an important game for us because we want a home game in the playoffs and it was Senior Night, too."
La Salle drove the ball to the Blue Devils' 24-yard line on the ensuing possession, but the chance to even the score at the half was denied on an interception by Jake Preston .
Columbia (4-2 overall, 3-1 Liberty Division) opened the second half by driving 62 yards for a touchdown, Dubuque running it in from nine yards out.
After forcing the Cadets to punt from deep in their own territory, the Blue Devils scored again on a 38-yard drive, capped by Dubuque's four-yard TD run.
"Dylan had a heck of a game for us," Cavotta said. "He worked hard and ran the ball with authority. The kids up front love blocking for him and our other backs."
La Salle (2-4, 2-2) got its lone score with 1:21 left in the third quarter when Kyle Borey took an option toss from quarterback Jack Field and found Bryan Miller all alone on a 42-yard touchdown pass.
"On defense, we planned for their trick plays and for the most part, we were disciplined and held them, except for that touchdown play," Dubuque said.
Columbia answered back, scoring its final touchdown with less than a minute gone in the fourth on Jeff Simoni 's 27-yard reception from Steve Lindemann .
Lindemann completed three of six passes for 87 yards, while Simoni had two catches for 76 yards, and also had an interception.
Amir Young had 67 yards on the ground and Joe Planz rushed for 54 yards to lead La Salle.
"This was a huge win for us," Cavotta said. "If they had won, they would have pretty much wrapped up the No. 2 seed. Now, we go to Bethlehem next week and control our own destiny."
Eric Houghtaling is a freelance writer.
